title: Is There an Eiffel Tower Emoji?

steps.title: Currently, there is no Unicode-approved Eiffel Tower emoji.
steps.content: Currently, there is no Unicode-approved Eiffel Tower emoji. If youâ€™re pre-planning your Instagram captions for your trip to Paris, youâ€™ll probably be disappointed to learn thereâ€™s no official Eiffel Tower emoji. This is despite the general feeling from emoji users that there â€œshould be oneâ€ because itâ€™s such an iconic landmark. Many emoji users swear there used to be an Eiffel Tower emoji, with some saying it used to be depicted inside of a square (like the ğŸŒ‰ (bridge at night) emoji). People may misremember the Eiffel Tower emojiâ€™s existence because of the similar looking ğŸ—¼ (Tokyo Tower) emoji and generic city emojis like ğŸŒ† (cityscape at dusk).

steps.title: The ğŸ—¼ (Tokyo Tower) is often confused for an Eiffel Tower emoji.
steps.content: The ğŸ—¼ (Tokyo Tower) is often confused for an Eiffel Tower emoji. The Tokyo Tower is the second-tallest structure in Japan and its design was inspired by the Eiffel Tower in Paris. Because of the similar structure and small size of emojis, many users mistake the Tokyo Tower for an Eiffel Tower emoji (even though it is colored orange). [1] X Research source The Tokyo Tower emoji was included in Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and Emoji 1.0 in August 2015, possibly tricking users into thinking it was the Eiffel Tower for over a decade. [2] X Research source The Tokyo Tower comes from the original set of Japanese emojis. In fact, â€œemojiâ€ comes from the Japanese â€œeâ€ (meaning â€œpictureâ€) and â€œmojiâ€ (meaning â€œcharacterâ€).

steps.title: Use or create an Eiffel Tower sticker in place of an actual emoji.
steps.content: Use or create an Eiffel Tower sticker in place of an actual emoji. While you canâ€™t add an actual Eiffel Tower emoji to your keyboard, there are other ways to celebrate la France with tiny images. Try creating a custom Eiffel Tower sticker based on your favorite image of the iconic landmark (note that it will appear as a small image in texts and not an in-line emoji): iPhone: Save a photo of the Eiffel Tower to your camera roll. Then, open the photo, tap and hold the subject (the Tower), and hit â€œAdd Sticker.â€ Your Eiffel Tower sticker will then be available to use in iMessage. [3] X Research source Android (custom stickers can be added to photos , but not to text messages): Open a picture to add a sticker to in your Gallery. Tap the â€œEditâ€ icon, then the â€œDecorationsâ€ icon, then â€œStickers,â€ then the â€œGalleryâ€ icon. Tap â€œCreate Stickerâ€ and select a saved image of the Eiffel Tower. Tap â€œFree-formâ€ and trace the outline of the sticker with your finger and hit â€œSnap to shape.â€ Drag the sticker onto your image and save. [4] X Research source Alternatively, purchase or download a sticker pack containing an Eiffel Tower image from the App Store or Google Play.

steps.title: The Eiffel Tower symbolizes Paris, French culture, and iconic architecture.
steps.content: The Eiffel Tower symbolizes Paris, French culture, and iconic architecture. Send an Eiffel Tower sticker or use it in a photo caption to express your love of all things French, talk about your trip to Paris, or admire fine architecture anywhere in the world. If you donâ€™t have a sticker handy, use the ğŸ—¼ (Tokyo Tower) or ğŸ‡«ğŸ‡· (French flag) as a substitute. â€œI canâ€™t wait to go back to Paris! ğŸ—¼â€ â€œI just love French architecture ğŸ‡«ğŸ‡·ğŸ—¼â¤ï¸â€

steps.title: An Eiffel Tower may also refer to the slang term for a sex position.
steps.content: An Eiffel Tower may also refer to the slang term for a sex position. In pop culture, â€œEiffel Towerâ€ is slang for a sex position involving 3 people (weâ€™ll leave it there). If you see an image of the Eiffel Tower (or itâ€™s emoji doppelganger, the Tokyo Tower) in a sexual context, thereâ€™s a good chance the person isnâ€™t talking about architecture.

steps.content: Try a ğŸ‡«ğŸ‡· (French flag) or ğŸ¥ (croissant) in place of the Eiffel Tower. If youâ€™re bummed about Unicodeâ€™s lack of Eiffel Tower, never fear! There are plenty of other emojis reminiscent of France (sometimes literally, like ğŸ‡«ğŸ‡·, or sometimes stereotypically, like ğŸ¥– (baguette)). Here are some to try: ğŸ‡«ğŸ‡· (French flag) ğŸ¥ (croissant) ğŸ¥– (baguette) ğŸ· (wine) ğŸ¾ (champagne) ğŸ§‘â€ğŸ¨ (artist wearing a beret) ğŸ–¼ï¸ (framed picture or painting, like the Mona Lisa at the Louvre)

steps.title: New emojis are voted on by the Unicode Consortium.
steps.content: New emojis are voted on by the Unicode Consortium. The Unicode Consortium is a nonprofit organization that standardizes how basic symbols and characters appear on screens regardless of device or language by assigning each character a unique number. [5] X Research source This includes emojis, and members of the Consortium from various tech companies (like Google and Apple) vote on which new emojis to roll out as they update the Unicode. [6] X Research source

steps.title: Propose a new emoji yourself by submitting a Unicode emoji proposal.
steps.content: Propose a new emoji yourself by submitting a Unicode emoji proposal. If youâ€™re dying to see a real Eiffel Tower emoji, submit an official Unicode emoji proposal that meets Unicodeâ€™s proposal guidelines . There are a variety of criteria an emoji must meet to be selected; for the highest chance of success, explain clearly how frequent the emoji will be used and submit a design that is clearly and quickly recognizable and distinct. [7] X Research source
